q.t: A student has plotted a velocity against time graph for a trolley moving down a ramp. Which of the following pair of quantities can be determined from the gradient of the graph and the area under the graph?

The diagram below shows the directions and magnitudes of the three forces acting on an object at a specific time as it moves through water. object0.60 N 1.20 N0.80 N The weight of the object is 1.20 N, the upthrust on the object is 0.80 N and the drag is 0.60 N. Which statement is correct about this object at this specific time?

o.t: It has reached its terminal velocity.

q.t: A particle X of mass m collides with a stationary particle Y of mass 4 m. Immediately after the collision the particle X is moving at velocity v1 at an angle of 60Â° to its original direction and the particle Y is moving with velocity v2 at 90Â° to the velocity of particle X. m 4mXXY Y60Â°v1 v2 Before collision After collision What is the value of the ratio v1 v2?

A metal block of mass m is heated by an electric heater. The graph of temperature Î¸ against time t for this block is shown below. 0203040 100 200 300 t / s/ Â°CÎ¸ The power of the heater is P. The gradient of the straight-line graph is G. What is the correct expression for the specific heat capacity c of the metal? m G mG

Which statement(s) below are implied by the assumptions of the kinetic theory model of gases? 1 A gas is mostly empty space. 2 Gas particles spend more time between collisions than time during collisions. 3 There are always forces between the gas particles.

A container has 1.0 mole of gas at pressure 100 kPa. The root mean square (r.m.s.) speed of the gas particles is 500 m sâ€“1. The mass of each gas particle is 4.7 Ã— 10â€“26 kg. What is the volume of the container?

A mass is attached to the bottom end of a spring which is fixed at its top end. The mass is displaced vertically, and then released. The mass oscillates with a simple harmonic motion. Which row correctly describes the energy of this spring-mass system when the mass is at its lowest point in its oscillations? Elastic potential energyGravitational potential energyKinetic energy

q.t: Which pair of quantities do not have the same, or equivalent, units?

The diagram shows three energy levels X, Y and Z of an electron within a gas atom. â€“8.0â€“6.0â€“ 4.0 energy / eVX Y Z Which transition is correct when the electron absorbs a photon with the shortest wavelength?

Light from a hydrogen source is incident normally at a diffraction grating. The first order maximum of the H-alpha spectral line of wavelength 486 nm is observed at angle of 30.0Â°. Light from a distant receding star is observed using the same diffraction grating. The light is incident normally at the grating as before. The speed of this star is 0.16 c, where c is the speed of light in a vacuum. What is the observed angle of the first order maximum of the H-alpha spectral line from the light of this receding star?

A galaxy, 1.0 Ã— 109 light-years away from the Earth, has a recession speed of 23 000 km sâ€“1. Which expression, based on the information above, is correct for the age of the universe in seconds? 23 000 Ã— 103 23 000 23 000 Ã— 103 23 000 Ã— 103
Astronomers observe approximately the same number of distant galaxies per unit volume of space in all directions. Which idea does this observation support? SECTION B Answer all the questions.

o.t: Big bang model of the universe

p.t: Describe how an experiment can be carried out to determine the force constant of an elastic cord in the laboratory by plotting a suitable graph. You may assume that the cord obeys Hookeâ€™s law

A simple catapult is made by an elastic cord fixed to two supports, as shown below. elastic cord fixed supports d The unstretched length of the cord is the same as the distance between the supports. The distance that the centre of the cord has been pulled back is d. The cord has a force constant of 500 N mâ€“1. The variation of the extension of the cord with distance d is shown below. 0 4 8 12 16extension / cm d / cm The ball is released and launched horizontally from a height of 1.5 m above the horizontal ground.
Use the graph to show that the elastic potential energy E in the cord is about 1 J.
Show that the maximum speed at which the ball leaves the catapult is about 8 m sâ€“1.
Calculate the horizontal distance R travelled by the ball before it strikes the horizontal ground. Ignore the effects of air resistance in your calculation. R = m
Explain how the value of R calculated in (iii) compares with the actual value

o.t: small ball of mass 30 g is placed at the centre of the cord and drawn back with d = 10 cm.

q.t: An electric engine of mass 17 000 kg has a constant power output of 280 kW and it can reach a maximum speed of 42 m sâ€“1 on horizontal rails. The maximum kinetic energy of the engine is 15 MJ.

p.t: The engine is initially at rest on long horizontal rails. Show that the minimum time taken for the engine to reach its maximum speed is about 1 minute.

The engine is moving along the horizontal rails at the constant maximum speed of 42 m sâ€“1. The weight of the engine is W, the total normal contact force from the rails is N and the total friction between the wheels and the rails is F. F is responsible for the motion of the engine to the right . Complete the free body diagram for the engine by showing a missing force, and the magnitudes of all the forces. There is space for you to do any calculations below the diagram. N = F = W = engine

The speed of the engine is 42 m sâ€“1. The driver sees an obstruction 167 m from the front of the engine. The engine is switched off and the brakes are applied. The constant force opposing motion is 120 kN. The reaction time of the driver is 0.40 s. Show with the help of calculations, that the engine will stop before reaching the obstruction.

Show that the mass of air which hits the tent in this time is about 490 kg.

All of the air incident on the shaded side of the tent is deflected at 90Â° to the original direction as shown in Fig. 18.2 . viewed from above tent wind direction Fig. 18.2 Use the information given in (a)(i) to calculate the magnitude of the force F exerted by the wind on the shaded side of the tent. p.t: A fixed mass of nitrogen changes phase from liquid to gas at a constant temperature. Explain the change in the total internal energy of nitrogen
In a factory, nitrogen gas is added to packets of food to keep it fresh for longer. In 1.0 hour, the factory uses 15 m3 of nitrogen at pressure 100 kPa and temperature 23 Â°C.
Show that the number of moles n, of nitrogen used per hour is about 600.
Calculate the mass of nitrogen gas used in one hour. molar mass of nitrogen = 0.028 kg molâ€“1 mass = kg
The volume of nitrogen being used cannot be changed. State how the rate of mass of nitrogen used can be reduced

The nitrogen at the factory is stored as a liquid. The liquid expands at constant temperature to form gas in a short section of pipe. When the air temperature is 0 Â°C, a thick layer of ice forms on the outside of the pipe from water vapour in the air. In 1.0 hour, the mass of ice formed is 1.3 kg at a temperature of 0 Â°C. Use the data below and your answer to (b)(ii) , to estimate the specific latent heat of vaporisation L of nitrogen. â€¢ specific latent heat of fusion of ice = 3.34 Ã— 105 J kgâ€“1 â€¢ specific latent heat of vaporisation of water = 2.26 Ã— 106 J kgâ€“1 L = J kgâ€“1

p.t: For a simple harmonic oscillator, the acceleration a is given by the equation a = â€“Ï‰ 2x, where Ï‰ is the angular frequency and x is the displacement. Show that this equation is homogeneous by reducing both sides to S.I. base units.

The diagram shows a glass U -tube partially filled with a mass of water. glass U-tube waterxto gas supply One end of the U -tube is connected to a gas supply of constant pressure and the other end is open to the atmosphere. The displacement of the water from its equilibrium position is x. The density Ï of water is 1000 kg mâ€“3.

The pressure from the gas supply raises the water in the U-tube. The vertical distance between the two levels of water in the two vertical sections of the U-tube is 10.0 cm (x = 5.0 cm). Î”p is the difference between the gas pressure and atmospheric pressure. Calculate Î”p. Î”p = Pa

When the gas supply is disconnected, the water levels in the U -tube oscillates with simple harmonic motion. The acceleration a of the water level in the left -hand side of the U-tube is given by the equation a = â€“ 2ÏgA m x where m is the mass of the water in the U -tube, A is the internal cross-sectional area of the U -tube, Ï is the density of water, g is the acceleration of free fall and x is the displacement of the water level in the left -hand side of the U -tube. For this U -tube, A = 1.0 Ã— 10â€“4 m2 and m = 0.052 kg. 1 Show that the period T of the oscillations is about 1 second. 2 The oscillations of the water level are slightly damped . At time t = 0, x = 5.0 cm. Sketch a suitable graph of displacement x against time t for the oscillating water level. Add suitable values to the time t axis. 5.0 â€“5.0x / cm 0 t / s 3 The U-tube is now connected to another gas supply where the pressure oscillates at a frequency of about 1 Hz. Explain the effect this will have on the water in the U-tube

p.t: A nebula is a giant cloud of gas and dust in space. The nebula can produce a star over a long period of time. State what causes the initial collapse of the nebula

Show that the volume of the nebula is 4.1 Ã— 1051 m3. 1 pc = 3.1 Ã— 1016 m Calculate the ratio mass of nebula X mass of the Sun. ratio =
Calculate the total kinetic energy Ek of the gas and dust particles in the nebula. Ek = J After a long time, nebula X will form a stable star. Describe the eventual evolution of this star

Explain whether the astronomers should attempt to measure T or L more precisely to reduce the uncertainty in r

p.t: A planet of mass m is in a circular orbit around a star of mass M. Use the equation for Newtonâ€™s law of gravitation and your knowledge of circular motion to show that the relationship between the orbital period T of the planet and its orbital radius r is T 2 ? r 3.

The Solar Orbiter satellite was launched in February 2020. This satellite moves around the Sun in an elliptical orbit with a period of 168 days. The diagram below shows the elliptical orbit of this satellite. satellite Sun The closest distance of the satellite to the Sun is 4.20 Ã— 1010 m and its furthest distance from the Sun is 1.37 Ã— 1011 m. The mass of the Sun is 2.0 Ã— 1030 kg and the mass of the satellite is 209 kg.

The Earth has a mean orbital distance of 1.50 Ã— 1011 m around the Sun and an orbital period of 365 days. Use Keplerâ€™s third law to calculate the mean orbital distance of the satellite from the Sun. distance = m

The total kinetic and gravitational potential energy of the satellite in its orbit remains constant. Calculate the change in the kinetic energy of the satellite as it travels from its furthest point from the Sun to its closest point to the Sun. change in kinetic energy = J

Suggest why the total energy of the satellite in its orbit around the Sun is not the same as the total energy of the satellite during its launch from the surface of the Earth ADDITIONAL ANSWER SPACE If additional space is required, you should use the following lined page(s).
